header_summary:
The release candidate for Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc1 has been announced by fanquake, signaling an important step toward the next major version. This update is available for testing, with binaries and source code accessible through [Bitcoin Core's official page](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/test.rc1/) and [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v30.0rc1), respectively. Preliminary release notes and a testing guide have also been provided to assist users and developers in evaluating the release candidate, emphasizing the significance of community feedback via a designated GitHub issue tracker [link](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/33368).

ZmnSCPxj et al. have delved into the potential of lattices in cryptography and the resilience of Lightning Network forwarding nodes, highlighting the complexities of lattice-based cryptography and the importance of high availability and strong consistency in distributed databases like YugabyteDB. The discussions underscore the need for specialist knowledge in advancing cryptographic protocols and the architectural considerations necessary for robust distributed systems, with further details available in the YugabyteDB documentation [here](https://docs.yugabyte.com/preview/architecture/design-goals/partition-tolerance-cap).

Danielabrozzoni explores the behavior of Bitcoin nodes in relation to fee filters, revealing insights into node responses across different software versions and operational states. A significant discovery was that nodes in the Initial Block Download (IBD) phase might not process or respond to feefilter requests as expected, a complexity that underscores the nuanced behavior of nodes within the Bitcoin network. This analysis contributes to a deeper understanding of protocol interactions and operational states in the Bitcoin ecosystem, as detailed [here](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/measuring-minrelaytxfee-across-the-bitcoin-network/1989/4).

Lastly, ZmnSCPxj proposes a novel approach for managing onchain fees within the Lightning Network, suggesting modifications to channel management and unilateral exit protocols to optimize onchain resource usage and enhance liquidity. By centralizing the payment of onchain fees to Lightning Service Providers (LSPs), the proposal aims to streamline fee management, reduce resource consumption, and ensure the latest channel state is always favored for confirmation. This strategy, which incorporates a dual-branch condition and a "sign, then revoke" practice for state updates, represents a comprehensive reimagining of fee management and channel state processes within the Lightning Network, as discussed [here](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/a-decker-wattenhofer-multichannel-for-reduced-inter-lsp-trust/1994/3).

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 30.0 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Core v30.0rc1 release candidate is now available, marking a significant update.
- Binaries and source code can be accessed on Bitcoin Core's official page and GitHub, respectively.
- Feedback can be submitted via GitHub, aiming for the final release of version v30.0.

recent_posts.title: MultiChannel and MultiPTLC: Towards A Global High-Availability Consistent/Partition-Tolerant Database For Bitcoin Payments
recent_posts.summary:
- Lattices in cryptography parallel ECC, offering potential for PTLC-like features.
- The complexity of lattice-based cryptography demands specialist knowledge for innovation.
- YugabyteDB's design for high availability and strong consistency in distributed systems highlights the need for a minimum of three nodes.

recent_posts.title: Measuring minrelaytxfee across the Bitcoin network
recent_posts.summary:
- An observation revealed varying responses of Bitcoin nodes to fee filters across software versions.
- Significant findings showed nodes on Core 27.x not replying, despite expected feefilter support.
- Nodes in Initial Block Download phase were found less likely to process or respond to feefilter requests.

recent_posts.title: A Decker-Wattenhofer MultiChannel For Reduced Inter-LSP Trust
recent_posts.summary:
- A new method in the Lightning Network uses exogenous fee UTXOs to improve onchain fee management.
- LSPs could cover onchain fees for unilateral exits, reducing resource use and increasing liquidity.
- The method involves dual-branch conditions and "sign, then revoke" for channel updates, enhancing efficiency.

active_posts.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
active_posts.summary:
- Jameson Lopp's proposal addresses enhancing Bitcoin's resilience to quantum threats.
- It suggests a phased migration to post-quantum cryptographic standards, including a new P2QRH address type.
- The strategy aims to unite the Bitcoin community in preemptively adopting quantum-resistant measures.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] No burn, Quantum Migration Proposal, Quantum Secure Asset Verification & Escrow (QSAVE)
active_posts.summary:
- The QSAVE proposal aims to protect Bitcoin from quantum threats through a wealth fund model.
- It seeks to safeguard vulnerable Bitcoins, preserving their value and utilizing returns for global welfare.
- The initiative includes a detailed protective strategy, funding management, and governance structure.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Standard Encrypted Wallet Payload + Standard Encryption Envelope formats
active_posts.summary:
- Two new Bitcoin Improvement Proposals aim to enhance wallet security and interoperability.
- The first proposal introduces a CBOR-based format for serializing wallet data with encryption standards.
- The second proposal outlines a secure, versioned container for the encrypted wallet payload.

active_posts.title: Stats on compact block reconstructions
active_posts.summary:
- Debugging with `debug=cmpctblock` highlights insights into Bitcoin's block reconstruction efficiency.
- Configuration changes, such as `mempoolfullrbf=1`, improved block reconstruction efficiency.
- Periods of high mempool activity correlated with decreased compact block reconstruction rates.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Recent years show shifts in Bitcoin mempool policies, including adoption of full replace-by-fee.
- Compact block relay significantly reduces block propagation times, aiding in network efficiency.
- Alternatives like weak blocks and template sharing are explored to improve network robustness.

active_posts.title: Addressing community concerns and objections regarding my recent proposal to relax Bitcoin Core's standardness limits on OP_RETURN outputs
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal suggests increasing `OP_RETURN` output limits to improve Bitcoin's data storage efficiency.
- Critics argue it might misappropriate Bitcoin for extensive data storage, altering its primary purpose.
- The debate highlights the importance of evaluating Bitcoin Core changes on technical merit, facing governance challenges.

today_in_history_posts.title: New transaction policies (nVersion=3) for contracting protocols
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin developers propose improvements to v3 transactions, including limiting OP_TRUE outputs.
- Changes also involve adding ephemeral outputs for CPFP fees and allowing below-dust outputs.
- Gloria Zhao proposes mempool policies for Layer 2 protocols, addressing pinning and fingerprinting concerns.

today_in_history_posts.title: `htlc_maximum_msat` as a valve for flow control on the Lightning Network
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rene Pickhardt explored `htlc_maximum_msat` for Lightning Network channel depletion mitigation.
- His research suggests asymmetric `htlc_maximum_msat` pairs reduce payment failure rates significantly.
- Algorithms adjust `htlc_maximum_msat` based on liquidity distribution, aiding node operators and LSPs.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin scaling aims for 50,000 off-chain entities to support 1 billion weekly users.
- Concepts like Utreexo optimize storage but don't solve centralization or scalability alone.
- Effective Layer 2 protocols and security against supply chain attacks are crucial for scalability.
